page.title: Final Check
page.introduction:
You have arrived at the end of the PAWS Starter Kit. As a final check of your work before you exit PAWS for the last time and begin working with the PC-Patr grammar file and the grammar writer files, any WARNING messages shown here need to be dealt with. These messages either tell you that you did not answer a question that has check boxes or that the answers you gave to two different questions are incompatible. Remember that if your language does not seem to have a particular construction, you should check the ‘Other’ option so you can say what your language does instead.
For each message shown, go to the page listed and make the appropriate corrections and then return here. That message should no longer show up.
If you do not correct these issues, the PC-Patr grammar rules and the grammar writeup will not be correct for your language. It will be much easier to correct these issues within PAWS, so please do not proceed until there are no WARNING messages showing below this box.
Note that if you dealt with the WARNING messages on each page earlier, you should not see any here now. Only those you missed or skipped will show up.

form.prompt:
From
Quantifiers and QP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how these degree elements or quantifiers attach in your language, or change the answer above to ‘Yes, they are all independent words’.

From
Quantifiers and QP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these degree words or quantifiers occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase’.

From
Quantifiers and QP - No other determiners, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these quantifiers occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase in your language, or change the answer above to "No, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase".

From
Quantifiers and QP - No other determiners, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how these quantifiers attach in your language, or change the answer above to "Yes, they are all independent words".

From
Quantifiers and QP - Other Quantifiers and Degree Words, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these degree words occur with respect to the quantifier in your language or change your answer above to say that the degree elements are not expressed as independent words.

From
Quantifiers and QP - Other Quantifiers and Degree Words, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these degree affixes occur with respect to the quantifier in your language or change your answer above to say that the degree elements are all written as independent words.

From
Quantifiers and QP - Numbers, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how the ordinal numbers are formed in your language.

From
Quantifiers and QP - Numbers, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where the ordinal word occurs with respect to the cardinal number to form the ordinal number in your language, or change your answer above to say that the ordinal numbers are formed in another way.

From
Quantifiers and QP - Numbers, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where the ordinal numbers and the words for ‘next’ and ‘last’ occur with respect to the cardinal number, unless your language does not allow either ordinal numbers or the words for ‘next’ or ‘last’ to occur with a cardinal number. In that case, select ‘Nowhere’ below.

From
Adverbs and AdvP, on the first page, WARNING: You said above that temporal adverbs may be modified or intensified, but you did not check any of the options. Please either check one or more options as appropriate, or change the answer above to "No, temporal adverbs are not modified or intensified".

From
Adverbs and AdvP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these degree words occur in your language, or change the answer above to a different type of modifier.

From
Adverbs and AdvP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how your language expresses these temporal indefinite meanings, unless your language does not have this kind of adverbial indefinite. In that case, select ‘None’ below.

From
Adverbs and AdvP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these quantifiers and general temporal words occur in your language, or change the answer above to a different form.

From
Adverbs and AdvP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how your language expresses this type of temporal indefinite meaning, unless your language does not have this kind of adverbial indefinite. In that case, select ‘None’ below.

From
Adverbs and AdvP, on the first page, WARNING: You have checked ‘None’ for both types of temporal adverbial indefinites. Please choose the type closest to the temporal adverbial indefinite in your language and describe it using the ‘My language...’ box. Uncheck ‘None’ for that option.

From
Adverbs and AdvP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these temporal interrogative adverbs and indefinite words occur in your language, or change the answer above to a different form.

From

From
Nominal Phrases - Overview, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where the classifiers occur with respect to these wide-scope quantifiers or degree words and the noun in your language, or change your answer above to “No, a classifier is never used in this type of nominal phrase”.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You need to check options for how nouns and their modifiers may/must agree in other features besides number, unless there is no type of agreement. In that case, select ‘None’ below.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers your language has noun class markers with concord agreement, so you should check that they agree in class number or type here and uncheck the box above for ‘None’.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers your language has a classifier which agrees with the class or type of the noun when nouns are counted or specified, so you should check that box here and uncheck the box above for ‘None’.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers your language has noun class markers with concord agreement, so you should check that they agree in class number or type here.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers that your language does not have a noun class or classifier system, so you should not check that they agree in class number or type here. If your language does have a noun class or classifier agreement system, please return to
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers and change your answer there before continuing here.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers your language has a simpler type of classifier system that does not include concord agreement within the nominal phrase, so you should not check that they agree in class number or type here. If your language does have a noun class or classifier system where concord agreement is required, please return to
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers and change your answer there before continuing here.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers your language has a classifier system that does not include concord agreement within the nominal phrase, so you should not check that they agree in class number or type here, but instead check the next box: ‘A classifier which agrees with the class or type of the noun is present with nouns that are counted or specified....’ If your language does have a noun class or classifier system where concord agreement is required, please return to
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers and change your answer there before continuing here.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Noun Classes and Classifiers your language has a classifier system that does not include concord agreement within the nominal phrase, so you should check the box: ‘A classifier which agrees with the class or type of the noun is present with nouns that are counted or specified....’ here.

Pronouns, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how these dependent pronouns attach in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No, only independent pronouns’.

From
Pronouns - Possessives, WARNING: You said above that your language has possessive pronouns, but you did not check any of the options to say how they are formed. Please either check one or more options as appropriate, unless you do not have any possessive pronouns, in which case you should not have added any forms to the text boxes and should change the answer above to ‘No’.

From
Pronouns - Reflexives, WARNING: You said above that your language has reflexives, but you did not check any of the options to say how they are formed. Please either check one or more options as appropriate, unless you do not have any reflexives, in which case you should not have added any forms to the text boxes and should change the answer above to either ‘No’ or ‘Yes, a verbal affix indicates reflexive action’.

From
Pronouns - Reciprocals, WARNING: You said above that your language has reciprocals, but you did not check any of the options to say how they are formed. Please either check one or more options as appropriate, unless you do not have any reciprocals, in which case you should not have added any forms to the text boxes and should change the answer above to either ‘No’ or ‘Yes, a verbal affix indicates reciprocal action’.

Pronouns - Indefinites, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these interrogative pronouns and indefinite words occur in your language, or change the answer above to a different form.

From
Adpositional Phrases, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these ordinal modifiers occur with respect to the rest of the PP in your language, or change the answer above to a different type of modifier. In that case, you should not have any examples of PPs with ordinal modifiers in the text box above.

From
Adpositional Phrases, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these manner adverbial modifiers occur with respect to the rest of the PP in your language, or change the answer above to a different type of modifier. In that case, you should not have any examples of PPs with manner adverbial modifiers in the text box above.

From
Adpositional Phrases, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these locative adverbial modifiers occur with respect to the rest of the PP in your language, or change the answer above to a different type of modifier. In that case, you should not have any examples of PPs with locative adverbial modifiers in the text box above.

From
Adpositional Phrases - Other Complements, WARNING: Since your language has only clitic prepositions, postpositions, prepositions and postpositions, it should not be possible for them to stand alone. If you do have forms which can stand alone, go back to the first page of this section and change the answer to ‘Some are written as independent words, but some are clitics written attached to another word’.

From
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features, WARNING: In
Pronouns you said that your language does not distinguish between exclusive and inclusive forms of the pronouns, yet you have checked some exclusive and inclusive features here. If your language does have exclusive and inclusive forms for any of the pronouns, including the dependent forms that can show up on verbs, please return to
Pronouns (first page) and change your answer to ‘Yes’. That will add additional textboxes for you to fill in for those forms for each appropriate case. If instead your language really does not distinguish between exclusive and inclusive features, please uncheck those features above.

From
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features, WARNING: In
Pronouns you said that your language has dependent pronouns and makes a distinction between exclusive and inclusive forms of the pronouns, yet you have not checked any exclusive or inclusive features here. It is therefore most likely that you need to check some or all of the exclusive and inclusive features above. Otherwise, please return to
Pronouns (first page) and change your answer to ‘No’, but that will mean that any forms you keyed in those textboxes will not be included in any output.

From
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features, WARNING: In
Pronouns you said that your language does not have different forms for singular and plural pronouns, yet you have checked some number features here. If your language does have singular and plural forms for any of the pronouns, including the dependent forms that can show up on verbs, please return to
Pronouns (first page) and change your answer to ‘Yes’. That will add additional textboxes for you to fill in for those forms for each appropriate case. If instead your language really does not distinguish between number features, please uncheck those features above.

From
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features, WARNING: In
Pronouns you said that your language has dependent pronouns and makes a distinction between singluar and plural forms of the pronouns, yet you have not checked any singular or plural features here. It is therefore most likely that you need to check some or all of the singular and plural features above. Otherwise, please return to
Pronouns (first page) and change your answer to ‘No, the pronouns only mark person’, but that will mean that any forms you keyed in the textboxes for plural will not be included in any output.

From
Basic Sentences - Auxiliaries, WARNING: In
Basic Sentences - Inflection Features you checked the -finite feature as occurring in your language. This is inconsistent with your answer here. Please either change your answer here to say your language does have infinitives or nonfinite forms, or return to
Basic Sentences - Inflection Features and uncheck the -finite feature.

From
Basic Sentences - Auxiliaries, WARNING: In
Basic Sentences - Inflection Features you did not check the -finite feature as occurring in your language. This is inconsistent with your answer here. If your language has infinitives or nonfinite forms, return to
Basic Sentences - Inflection Features and check the -finite feature.

From
Basic Sentences - Pro-Drop and Imperatives, WARNING: You did not check any boxes to describe when the subject may be missing from its normal position in your language. If it is truly not ever allowed to be missing, please check the box for ‘None’ below.

From
Basic Sentences - Conditionals, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how these conditional markers attach in your language, or change the answer above to ‘Yes, they are all independent words’ or ‘No, the only marker for conditionals in my language is the conditional mood itself marked on the verb’.

From
Basic Sentences - Conditionals, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these condition markers occur with respect to the rest of the conditional phrase in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No, they all attach to another word in the conditional phrase’ or ‘No, the only marker for conditionals in my language is the conditional mood itself marked on the verb’.

From
Basic Sentences - Subjunctives, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how these subjunctive conditional markers attach in your language, or change the answer above to ‘Yes, they are all independent words’ or ‘No, there is no marker for the conditional in subjunctives in my language, only the subjunctive mood itself marked on the verb’.

From
Basic Sentences - Subjunctives, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these subjunctive condition markers occur with respect to the rest of the subjunctive conditional phrase in your language, or change the answer to one of the ‘No’ answers above.

From
Basic Sentences - Existentials, WARNING: You did not check any boxes to describe how existential sentences are marked in your language. Please check at least one of the above options. if none truly apply, please check the box for ‘None’ below.

From

Basic Sentences - Inflection Features you checked the passive feature as occurring in your language. This is inconsistent with your answer here. Please either change your answer here to say your language does have passives, or return to
Basic Sentences - Inflection Features and uncheck the passive feature.

From

From
Basic Sentences - Other Voice Marking, WARNING: In
Basic Sentences - Inflection Features you checked some or all of the voice features as occurring in your language and hopefully also keyed in the morphemes. Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how your language expresses the negative temporal meaning.

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these negative words occur in your language, or change the answer above as to how the negative temporal adverbs are related to the positive forms.

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how your language expresses the negative locative meaning.

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these negative words occur in your language, or change the answer above as to how the negative locative adverbs are related to the positive forms.

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how negation of the verb or auxiliary is expressed in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No’.

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING - The answers you have entered are incompatible!! A negative auxiliary word cannot require the presence of another auxiliary if your language does not have (positive) auxiliaries that are written as independent words. Please change your answer either here or in
Basic Sentences - Auxiliaries to correct this problem before proceeding.

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING - The answers you have entered are incompatible!! A negative auxiliary affix cannot attach to anything if your language does not have (positive) auxiliaries that are written as independent words. Please change your answer either here or in
Basic Sentences - Auxiliaries to correct this problem before proceeding.

From
Coordination Constructions, on the first page, WARNING: You did not check any boxes to describe how the conjunctions may attach in your language. Please check one or more boxes as appropriate, or change your answer above to ‘Yes, they are all independent words’.

From
Focus and Topic Constructions, WARNING: You did not check any boxes to describe where the topic marker may occur with respect to the topic phrase in your language. Please check one or more boxes, or change your answer to ‘No, the topic is unmarked except for position’ above, in which case you should not have any examples of topic markers in the box either.

From
Focus and Topic Constructions, WARNING: You did not check any boxes to describe where the focus marker may occur with respect to the focus phrase in your language. Please check one or more boxes, or change your answer to ‘No, the focused phrase is unmarked except for position’ above, in which case you should not have any examples of focus markers in the box either.

From
Greetings, Interjections and Exclamations, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where the words which mark an exclamation may occur in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No’. In that case there should not be examples in the textbox above.
form.introduction:
Once there are no WARNING messages showing above, we suggest you also recheck the main page in
Pronouns to make sure it asked you for the correct number of sets of pronouns for your language. If not, please follow the instructions there about changing your answer in
Overall Typology Questions - Case System. If you do make a change regarding the case system it will change many other answers throughout, so be sure to return here after redoing the pronouns to see if any new WARNING messages need to be taken care of.
form.instruction:
Please save the PC-Patr grammar file (.grm) with a different name before editing it. Contact Cheri_Black@sil.org for help on how to proceed or how to handle specific constructions if you are using PC-Patr for parsing and disambiguation.
The following table provides a a list of the places where you noted that your language does something different than what was covered in PAWS. These will require special rules in PC-Patr. We suggest you copy and paste this table into a Word or Open Office Writer or XLingPaper file before exiting PAWS, so that this information will be available when you work with a consultant on editing the PC-Patr grammar file.

tr.td: Case system overall

My language has a Nominative-Accusative system normally, but the Ergative-Absolutive system is used under the following grammatical conditions: (Note that all the rules for both the Nominative-Accusative and Ergative-Absolutive case systems have been added to your PC-Patr grammar file. You will need to add the appropriate conditions to the rules, based on your answer here.)
Wide scope Quantifiers in DP
Where do these degree elements or wide scope quantifiers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase?
Wide scope Quantifiers in DP
Where do these degree elements or wide scope quantifiers that are not independent words attach within the nominal phrase?
Quantifier determiners in DP
Where do these quantifiers which are written as independent words and act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase?
Quantifier determiners in DP
Where do these quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase that are not independent words attach within the nominal phrase?
Degree words in QP
Where do the degree words occur with respect to the quantifier?
Degree modifiers in QP
Where do the degree elements that are not independent words attach with respect to the quantifier?
Ordinal Numbers in QP
How are ordinal numbers formed in your language?
Ordinal Numbers in QP
Where does the ordinal word occur with respect to the cardinal number to form the ordinal number?
Ordinal Numbers in QP
Where do ordinal numbers and the words for ‘next’ and ‘last’ occur with respect to the cardinal number in phrases like ‘the first twenty boys’ or ‘the last five books’,?
Degree words in AdvP
My language does the following to intensify the meaning of the temporal adverb:
Degree words in AdvP
Where do the degree words occur with respect to the temporal adverb?
Indefinites in AdvP
How does your language express the temporal adverbial indefinites that include a quantifier, such as ‘everytime’, ‘anytime’ and ‘sometime’?
Indefinites in AdvP
Where does the quantifier occur with respect to the general temporal noun in these temporal indefinites?
Indefinites in AdvP
How does your language express the temporal adverbial indefinites that are based on the temporal interrogative word and an indefinite word, such as ‘whenever’?
Indefinites in AdvP
Where does the temporal interrogative word occur with respect to the indefinite word in these temporal indefinites?
Degree words in AdvP
My language does the following to intensify the meaning of the locative adverb:
Degree words in AdvP
Where do the degree words occur with respect to the locative adverb?
Indefinites in AdvP
How does your language express the locative adverbial indefinites that include a quantifier, such as ‘everywhere’ and ‘somewhere’?
Indefinites in AdvP
Where does the quantifier occur with respect to the general locative noun in these locative indefinites?
Indefinites in AdvP
How does your language express the locative adverbial indefinites that are based on the locative interrogative word and an indefinite word, such as ‘wherever’?
Indefinites in AdvP
Where does the locative interrogative word occur with respect to the indefinite word in these locative indefinites?
Degree words in AdvP
How does your language express the intensity of the manner adverbs which are independent words?
Degree words in AdvP
Where do the degree words occur with respect to the manner adverb?
Degree affixes in AdvP
How does your language express the intensity of the manner adverbs which are affixes?
Modifiers in AdjP
How does your language modify adjectives?
Modifiers in AdjP
Where do the degree words occur with respect to the adjective?
Modifiers in AdjP
Where do the manner adverbs occur with respect to the adjective?
Classifiers in DP
Where do the classifiers occur with respect to these wide-scope quantifiers or degree words and the noun?
Agreement in NP/DP
Which additional features on nouns may or must be marked on modifiers so that they agree with the head noun?
Case marking in DP
Where do these case markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase?
Case marking in DP
Where do these case markers that are not independent words attach within the nominal phrase?
Articles in DP
Where does the article occur with respect to the noun?
Demonstratives in DP
Where does the demonstrative occur with respect to the noun?
Classifiers in DP
Where do the classifiers occur with respect to the demonstratives and the noun?
Articles or Demonstratives in DP
Where does the demonstrative or article occur with respect to the noun?
Articles in DP
Where does the article occur with respect to the noun?
Demonstratives in DP
Where does the demonstrative occur with respect to the noun?
Classifiers in DP
Where do the classifiers occur with respect to the demonstratives and the noun?
Possessors in NP
Where does the possessive marker word occur with respect to the possessor?
Quantifiers and numbers in NP
Where do narrow scope quantifier phrases (including cardinal numbers) occur with respect to the noun?
Classifiers in NP
Where do the classifiers occur with respect to the quantifier or number and the noun?
Adjectives in NP
Where do adjective phrases occur with respect to the noun?
Classifiers in NP
Where do the classifiers occur with respect to the adjective and the noun?
Pronouns in NP
Where do the dependent pronouns attach to the verb or noun or other words?
Pronouns in NP
How are the stand alone possessive pronouns (or phrases) built in your language?
Pronouns in NP
How are the reflexives that fill the object position formed in your language?
Pronouns in NP
How are the reciprocals that fill the object position formed in your language?
Indefinites in NP
How does your language express the indefinites that include a quantifier, such as ‘everybody’ and ‘something’?
Indefinites in NP
Where does the quantifier occur with respect to the generic noun in these indefinites?
Indefinites in NP
How does your language express the indefinites that are based on an interrogative pronoun and an indefinite word, such as ‘whoever’ and ‘whatever’?
Indefinites in NP
Where does the interrogative pronoun occur with respect to the indefinite word in these indefinites?
Modifiers in PP
Which other modifiers occur either before or after PPs as independent words?
Modifiers in PP
Where do these degree words occur with respect to the rest of the PP?
Modifiers in PP
Where do these ordinals occur with respect to the rest of the PP?
Modifiers in PP
Where do these manner adverbials occur with respect to the rest of the PP?
Modifiers in PP
Where do these locative adverbials occur with respect to the rest of the PP?
Pro-Drop in IP/VP
Under what other circumstances can a subject be missing from its normal position?
Conditionals in VP
Where do the condition markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the conditional phrase?
Conditionals in VP
Where do the condition markers that are not independent words attach within the conditional phrase?
Subjunctives in VP
Where do the subjunctive condition markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the conditional phrase?
Subjunctives in VP
Where do the subjunctive condition markers that are not independent words attach within the conditional phrase?
Existentials in VP
What other special elements are used in your language especially in existential sentences?
Causatives in VP
What other ways are used in your language to express causatives?
Antipassives in VP
What other ways are used in your language to express antipassives?
Complementizers in CP
Where do the complementizers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the complement clause?
Complementizers in CP
Where do the complementizers that are not independent words attach within the complement clause?
Question markers in CP
Where do the Yes/No question markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the Yes/No question markers that are not independent words attach within the question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the Yes/No question markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the embedded question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the Yes/No question markers that are not independent words attach within the embedded question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the question markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the question markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the question markers that are not independent words attach within the question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the question markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the embedded question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the question markers which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the embedded question?
Question markers in CP
Where do the question markers that are not independent words attach within the embedded question?
Relative clauses in CP
What other types of relative clauses does your language have?
Relative clauses in CP
Where does the relative marker word occur with respect to the sentence part of the relative clause?
Neg in DP
Where do the negative elements which are written as independent words occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase?
Neg in DP
Where do the negative elements that are not independent words attach within the nominal phrase?
Negatives in AdvP
How else does your language express the negative temporal meaning of 'never' or 'at no time'?
Negatives in AdvP
Where do the negative words occur with respect to the positive temporal adverb?
Negatives in AdvP
How else does your language express the negative locative meaning of 'nowhere' or 'at no place'?
Negatives in AdvP
Where do the negative words occur with respect to the positive locative adverb?
Negatives in IP or VP
How else does your language express negation on either an auxiliary or the verb?
Coordination in S, CP, IP, VP, DP, AdjP, AdvP, QP
In my language, the conjunctions may attach in this other way within the coordination construction:
TopicP
Where does the topic marker occur with respect to the topic itself?
FocusP
Where does the focus marker occur with respect to the focused phrase itself?
Exclamations in S
Where does the particular word or words that signal an exclamation occur with respect to the adjective phrase?

form.introduction:
You have now completed the PAWS Starter Kit. You may view the grammar drafts by double clicking on the .htm files.
Please save the .xml versions under a different file name before you begin editing. For a nice XML editor for the grammar writeup, we personally prefer the XMLMind XML Editor It makes editing and printing a pdf version much easier, since special addons are available to handle all the extra features of XLingPaper, which the grammar writeup is using. You can find out more information at http://www.xlingpaper.org/.
You may now exit PAWS for your final time. Congratulations!
